messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Towards Sub-Quadratic Diameter Computation in Geometric Intersection Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract We initiate the study of diameter computation in geometric intersection graphs from the fine-grained complexity perspective. A geometric intersection graph is a graph whose vertices correspond to some shapes in dùëëd-dimensional Euclidean space, such as balls, segments, or hypercubes, and whose edges correspond to pairs of intersecting shapes. The diameter of a graph is the largest distance realized by a pair of vertices in the graph. Computing the diameter in near-quadratic time is possible in several classes of intersection graphs [Chan and Skrepetos 2019], but it is not at all clear if these algorithms are optimal, especially since in the related class of planar graphs the diameter can be computed in ùí™~‚Äã(n5/3)~ùí™superscriptùëõ53\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(n^{5/3}) time [Cabello 2019, Gawrychowski et al. 2021]. In this work we (conditionally) rule out sub-quadratic algorithms in several classes of intersection graphs, i.e., algorithms of running time ùí™‚Äã(n2‚àíŒ¥)ùí™superscriptùëõ2ùõø\mathcal{O}(n^{2-\delta}) for some Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0. In particular, there are no sub-quadratic algorithms already for fat objects in small dimensions: unit balls in ‚Ñù3superscript‚Ñù3\mathbb{R}^{3} or congruent equilateral triangles in ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2}. For unit segments and congruent equilateral triangles, we can even rule out strong sub-quadratic approximations already in ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2}. It seems that the hardness of approximation may also depend on dimensionality: for axis-parallel unit hypercubes in ‚Ñù12superscript‚Ñù12\mathbb{R}^{12}, distinguishing between diameter 2 and 3 needs quadratic time (ruling out (3/2‚àíŒµ)32ùúÄ(3/2-\varepsilon)- approximations), whereas for axis-parallel unit squares, we give an algorithm that distinguishes between diameter 222 and 333 in near-linear time. Note that many of our lower bounds match the best known algorithms up to sub-polynomial factors. Ultimately, this fine-grained perspective may enable us to determine for which shapes we can have efficient algorithms and approximation schemes for diameter computation.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "More consequences of falsifying SETH and the orthogonal vectors conjecture",
        "More applications of the polynomial method to algorithm design",
        "Fast estimation of diameter and shortest paths (without matrix multiplication)",
        "The fine-grained complexity of multi-dimensional ordering properties",
        "Toward tight approximation bounds for graph diameter and eccentricities",
        "Solutions to Klee‚Äôs rectangle problems",
        "EPTAS and subexponential algorithm for maximum clique on disk and unit ball graphs",
        "4 vs 7 sparse undirected unweighted diameter is SETH-hard at time n4/3",
        "Inapproximability of diameter in super-linear time: Beyond the 5/3 ratio",
        "On linear and circular structure of (claw, net)-free graphs",
        "A fine-grained analogue of Schaefer‚Äôs theorem in P: dichotomy of ‚àÉk‚àÄ-quantified first-order graph properties",
        "Subquadratic algorithms for the diameter and the sum of pairwise distances in planar graphs",
        "New bounds for approximating extremal distances in undirected graphs",
        "Polynomial-time approximation schemes for packing and piercing fat objects",
        "All-pairs shortest paths in unit-disk graphs in slightly subquadratic time",
        "All-pairs shortest paths in geometric intersection graphs",
        "Approximate shortest paths and distance oracles in weighted unit-disk graphs",
        "Deterministic APSP, orthogonal vectors, and more: Quickly derandomizing Razborov-Smolensky",
        "Better approximation algorithms for the graph diameter",
        "Lexicographic breadth first search - A survey",
        "Diameter determination on restricted graph families",
        "On the power of BFS to determine a graph‚Äôs diameter",
        "Hardness of approximate diameter: Now for undirected graphs",
        "Tight conditional lower bounds for approximating diameter in directed graphs",
        "Tight approximation algorithms for bichromatic graph diameter and related problems",
        "Almost diameter of a house-hole-free graph in linear time via LexBFS",
        "LexBFS-orderings and powers of graphs",
        "Well-separated pair decomposition for the unit-disk graph metric and its applications",
        "Voronoi diagrams on planar graphs, and computing the diameter in deterministic O~‚Äã(n5/3) time",
        "Approximation schemes for covering and packing problems in image processing and VLSI",
        "NC-approximation schemes for NP- and PSPACE-hard problems for geometric graphs",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Kontaktprobleme der konformen Abbildung",
        "Ad hoc networks beyond unit disk graphs",
        "On finding the maxima of a set of vectors",
        "Finding small satisfying assignments faster than brute force: A fine-grained perspective into boolean constraint satisfaction",
        "Settling SETH vs. approximate sparse directed unweighted diameter (up to (NU)NSETH)",
        "Tight hardness for shortest cycles and paths in sparse graphs",
        "On the complexity of the subgraph problem",
        "Fast approximation algorithms for the diameter and radius of sparse graphs",
        "On the all-pairs-shortest-path problem in unweighted undirected graphs",
        "Undirected single-source shortest paths with positive integer weights in linear time",
        "The measure problem for rectangular ranges in d-space",
        "On some fine-grained questions in algorithms and complexity",
        "A new algorithm for optimal 2-constraint satisfaction and its implications"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Towards Sub-Quadratic Diameter Computation in Geometric Intersection Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
